title: The Ape

credits[2].name: Maris Wrixon
credits[3].name: Gene O'Donnel
credits[4].name: Dorothy Vaughan
credits[5].name: Gertrude Hoffman
description: Karloff's nuanced performance as the well-meaning but demented scientist is the one redeeming feature in this cheaply made horror melodrama which provides very little in the way of horror or drama.

title: Before I Hang
credits[0].name: Nick Grinde
credits[1].name: Boris Karloff
credits[2].name: Evelyn Keyes
credits[3].name: Bruce Bennet
credits[4].name: Edward Van Sloan
credits[5].name: Ben Taggart
description: Karloff gives great face as the kindly doctor who inadvertantly turns himself into a maniacal killer in this rather stuffy melodramatic thriller from Columbia Pictures.

title: Black Friday
credits[0].name: Arthur Lubin
credits[1].name: Boris Karloff
credits[2].name: Bela Lugosi
credits[3].name: Stanley Ridges
credits[4].name: Ann Nagel
credits[5].name: Anne Gwynne
description: Karloff and Lugosi team up in what amounts to more of a crime drama with supernatural elements than a straight horror film.

title: Calling Philo Vance
credits[0].name: William Clemens
credits[1].name: James Stephenson
credits[2].name: Margot Stevenson
credits[3].name: Henry O'Neill
credits[4].name: Edward Brophy
credits[5].name: Sheila Bromley
description: Warner Brothers' series of films based on S.S. Van Dine's famous sleuth takes a serious downhill turn in attempting to blend international espionage into the cavalier detective's capers.

title: Chamber of Horrors
credits[0].name: Norman Lee
credits[1].name: Leslie Banks
credits[2].name: Lilli Palmer
credits[3].name: Romilly Lunge
credits[4].name: Gina Malo
credits[5].name: David Horne
description: Leslie Banks is as menacing as you'd expect in the role of demented villain, and Lilli Palmer is coolly lovely as the unsuspecting heiress in this atmospheric wartime charmer from the U.K.

title: Crimes at the Dark House
credits[0].name: George King
credits[1].name: Tod Slaughter
credits[2].name: Silvia Marriott
credits[3].name: Hilary Eaves
credits[4].name: Geoffrey Wardwell
credits[5].name: Hay Petrie
description: Slaughter chews the scenery in this lurid melodrama based loosely on the Wilkie Collins novel The Woman in White"
column20: and yet he conveys such a sinister aspect that you understand why he caused a sensation as the "Horror Man of Europe"."

title: Dark Streets of Cairo
credits[0].name: Laszlo Kardos
credits[1].name: Sigrid Gurie
credits[2].name: Ralph Byrd
credits[3].name: Eddie Quillan
credits[4].name: George Zucco
credits[5].name: Katherine DeMille
description: In this justifiably obscure Universal thriller, what's memorable to me is the dignified selflessness displayed at the end by Katherine DeMille as the wife of heavy George Zucco.

title: The Devil Bat
credits[0].name: Jean Yarbrough
credits[1].name: Bela Lugosi
credits[2].name: Suzanne Kaaren
credits[3].name: Dave O'Brien
credits[4].name: Guy Usher
credits[5].name: Yolande Donlan
description: This over-the-top PRC potboiler has long been the object of ridicule among Lugosi followers due to its comically over-the-top script; however, Bela as always acquits himself honorably despite the mire he's surrounded with.

title: Doomed to Die
credits[0].name: William Nigh
credits[1].name: Boris Karloff
credits[2].name: Marjorie Reynolds
credits[3].name: Grant Withers
credits[4].name: William Stelling
credits[5].name: Catherine Craig
description: Karloff returns as Mr. Wong to solve a not-very-interesting murder case and bail out Withers' obnoxious Captain Street in this Monogram snoozefest redeemed only slightly by the feisty Ms. Reynolds.

title: The Fatal Hour
credits[0].name: William Nigh
credits[1].name: Boris Karloff
credits[2].name: Grant Withers
credits[3].name: Marjorie Reynolds
credits[4].name: Charles Trowbridge
credits[5].name: Frank Puglia
description: Another feeble chapter in the Mr. Wong saga (Monogram's Charlie Chan knockoff), salvaged to a certain degree by the charisma of Mr. Karloff and Ms. Reynolds.

title: The Frightened Lady
credits[0].name: George King
credits[1].name: Marius Goring
credits[2].name: Helen Haye
credits[3].name: Penelope Dudley-Ward
credits[4].name: Patrick Barr
credits[5].name: John Warwick
description: This is a satisfying British chiller with an air of genuine mystery, an abundance of atmosphere, and a thoroughly well-conceived twist ending.

title: Gaslight
credits[0].name: Thorold Dickinson
credits[1].name: Anton Walbrook
credits[2].name: Diana Wynyard
credits[3].name: Frank Pettingell
credits[4].name: Cathleen Cordell
credits[5].name: Robert Newton
description: Generally this British original stands up well to the MGM remake 4 years later (Pettingell's portrayal of the kindly retired bobby who solves the case is particularly sympathetic), but Wynyard's over-the-top hystericalness  detracts.

title: Haunted House
credits[0].name: Robert F. McGowan
credits[1].name: Marcia Mae Jones
credits[2].name: Jackie Moran
credits[3].name: George Cleveland
credits[4].name: Christian Rub
credits[5].name: Henry Hall
description: This Monogram offering is not so much of a haunted house story as a not very engaging murder mystery sleuthed by a kid reporter who's speech and mannerisms make him a dead ringer for Wally Cleaver from the 1950s TV show.

title: The House of the Seven Gables
credits[0].name: Joe May
credits[1].name: George Sanders
credits[2].name: Margaret Lindsay
credits[3].name: Vincent Price
credits[4].name: Dick Foran
credits[5].name: Nan Grey
description: Universal's adaptation of the Nathaniel Hawthorne novel is really a melodrama with mystery overtones, as opposed to an actual horror film; still it's generally well-acted and remains true to the heart-rending spirit of the original.

title: Human Monster
credits[0].name: Walter Summers
credits[1].name: Bela Lugosi
credits[2].name: Hugh Williams
credits[3].name: Greta Gynt
credits[4].name: Edmon Ryan
credits[5].name: Wilfred Walter
description: Lugosi scintillates in this dual-faceted role as both a kindly proprietor of a home for the blind and an evil doctor who tortures and murders his victims.

title: The Invisible Man Returns
credits[0].name: Joe May
credits[1].name: Cedric Hardwicke
credits[2].name: Vincent Price
credits[3].name: Nan Grey
credits[4].name: John Sutton
credits[5].name: Cecil Kellaway
description: Vincent Price has the perfect voice to accompany the nicely-turned special effects in this sequel which inverts the premise of the original by having the potion used for the noble purpose of exonerating an innocent man wrongly convicted.

title: The Invisible Woman
credits[0].name: A. Edward Sutherland
credits[1].name: Virginia Bruce
credits[2].name: John Barrymore
credits[3].name: John Howard
credits[4].name: Charles Lane
credits[5].name: Shemp Howard
description: Carrying off the uncommon feat of presenting comedy that's truly funny in a horror vehicle, this film features John Barrymore as the screwy scientist and Shemp Howard as one of a lame-brained pack of gangsters.

title: The Lone Wolf Keeps a Date
credits[0].name: Sidney Salkow
credits[1].name: Warren William
credits[2].name: Frances Robinson
credits[3].name: Bruce Bennett
credits[4].name: Eric Blore
credits[5].name: Thurston Hall

title: The Man with Nine Lives
credits[0].name: Nick Grinde
credits[1].name: Boris Karloff
credits[2].name: Roger Pryor
credits[3].name: Jo Ann Sayers
credits[4].name: Stanley Brown
credits[5].name: John Dilson
description: It's hard not to enjoy Karloff in these mad scientist performances which he imbues with a degree of sincerity that the script rarely warrants.

title: Michael Shayne, Private Detective
credits[0].name: Eugene Forde
credits[1].name: Lloyd Nolan
credits[2].name: Marjorie Weaver
credits[3].name: Joan Valerie
credits[4].name: Walter Abel
credits[5].name: Elizabeth Patterson
description: Certainly the performances exhibit a certain charm, but this 20th Century Fox gumshoe mystery is too ambitious in its attempt to squeeze all the plot elements from the novel into the movie, making for a preposterous denouement.

title: The Mummy's Hand
credits[0].name: Christy Cabanne
credits[1].name: Dick Foran
credits[2].name: Peggy Moran
credits[3].name: Wallace Ford
credits[4].name: George Zucco
credits[5].name: Tom Tyler
description: The best of the Mummy non-sequels (which is really not saying much), this outing includes decent comic relief along with episodes of semi-convincing danger provided by Zucco as the high priest and Tyler as Kharis.

title: Phantom of Chinatown
credits[0].name: Phil Rosen
credits[1].name: Keye Luke
credits[2].name: Grant Withers
credits[3].name: Lotus Long
credits[4].name: Charles F. Miller
credits[5].name: Huntley Gordon
description: A script really couldn't get any lamer than in this Mr. Wong detective mystery from Monogram; however, there is some nifty flashback footage of the archeological expedition in China.

title: You'll Find Out
credits[0].name: David Butler
credits[1].name: Kay Kyser
credits[2].name: Peter Lorre
credits[3].name: Boris Karloff
credits[4].name: Bela Lugosi
credits[5].name: Helen Parrish
description: With Peter Lorre, Boris Karloff and Bela Lugosi, you might figure this movie would be terrific; give it a viewing and you'll find out" otherwise."

title: Among the Living
credits[0].name: Stuart Heisler
credits[1].name: Albert Dekker
credits[2].name: Susan Hayward
credits[3].name: Harry Carey
credits[4].name: Frances Farmer
credits[5].name: Gordon Jones
description: It appears that Albert Dekker would struggle enough under the weight of a single serious role, let alone portraying twin brothers with one of the twins being mentally insane.

title: The Black Cat
credits[0].name: Albert S. Rogell

credits[2].name: Bela Lugosi
credits[3].name: Gale Sondergaard
credits[4].name: Alan Ladd
credits[5].name: Broderick Crawford

title: The Devil Commands

credits[2].name: Richard Fiske
credits[3].name: Amanda Duff
credits[4].name: Anne Revere
credits[5].name: Cy Schindell

title: Footsteps in the Dark
credits[0].name: Lloyd Bacon
credits[1].name: Errol Flynn
credits[2].name: Brenda Marshall
credits[3].name: Ralph Bellamy
credits[4].name: Alan Hale
credits[5].name: Lee Patrick
description: You'd think that Errol Flynn with his charisma and good looks would be a natural for the romantic lead in a crime comedy; and boy would you be wrong.

title: The Gay Falcon
credits[0].name: Irving Reis
credits[1].name: George Sanders
credits[2].name: Wendy Barrie
credits[3].name: Allen Jenkins
credits[4].name: Nina Vale
credits[5].name: Gladys Cooper
description: A classy initiation for the long-running detective series, enlivened by the charisma of Allen Jenkins in the role of the Falcon's uncouth sidekick and Nina Vale as his feisty fiancee.

title: Horror Island
credits[0].name: George Waggner

credits[2].name: Leo Carrillo
credits[3].name: Peggy Moran
credits[4].name: Fuzzy Knight
credits[5].name: John Eldredge

title: Invisible Ghost
credits[0].name: Joseph H. Lewis
credits[1].name: Bela Lugosi
credits[2].name: Polly Ann Young
credits[3].name: John McGuire
credits[4].name: Clarence Muse
credits[5].name: Terry Walker
description: An interesting premise is compromised by the bewildering absence of any plausible  motivations for the characters and the incomprehensible outcomes of their actions.

title: King of the Zombies
credits[0].name: Jean Yarbrough

credits[2].name: Joan Woodbury
credits[3].name: Mantan Moreland
credits[4].name: Henry Victor
credits[5].name: John Archer

credits[3].name: Evelyn Keyes
credits[4].name: Elsa Lanchester
credits[5].name: Edith Barret

title: The Lone Wolf Takes a Chance
credits[0].name: Sidney Salkow
credits[1].name: Warren William
credits[2].name: June Storey
credits[3].name: Henry Wilcoxon
credits[4].name: Eric Blore
credits[5].name: Thurston Hall

credits[3].name: Anne Nagel
credits[4].name: Frank Albertson
credits[5].name: Samuel S. Hinds

title: The Smiling Ghost
credits[0].name: Lewis Seiler

credits[3].name: Alexis Smith
credits[4].name: Alan Hale
credits[5].name: Lee Patrick

credits[2].name: Leo Gorcey
credits[3].name: Bobby Jordan
credits[4].name: Dorothy Short
credits[5].name: Ernest Morrison
description: Considering how few movies of the genre I've rated this poorly, and the fact that  despite the presence of Bela in the cast this effort still warrants only two stars, I'll let you draw your own conclusions as to its quality.

title: The Wolf Man
credits[0].name: George Waggner

credits[2].name: Bela Lugosi
credits[3].name: Claude Rains
credits[4].name: Maria Ouspenskaya
credits[5].name: Evelyn Ankers
description: Even a man who is pure Yankee at heart and speaks with a heavy American blight
column20: may become a Welsh-bred manor lord when Hollywood scenarists' imaginations shine bright.""

title: Black Dragons
credits[0].name: William Nigh

credits[2].name: John Barclay
credits[3].name: George Pembroke
credits[4].name: Clayton Moore
credits[5].name: Robert Frazer

credits[5].name: Jeff Donnell
description: Reminiscent of Arsenic and Old Lace"

credits[3].name: Wanda McKay
credits[4].name: Tom Neal
credits[5].name: Vince Barnett

credits[5].name: Jack Holt

credits[5].name: Minerva Urecal

credits[2].name: Wendy Barrie
credits[3].name: James Gleason
credits[4].name: Allen Jenkins
credits[5].name: Mona Maris

credits[3].name: Lynne Roberts
credits[4].name: George Zucco
credits[5].name: Bert Roach

credits[2].name: Ann Harding
credits[3].name: Donna Reed
credits[4].name: Stephen McNally
credits[5].name: Katherine Emery
description: These wartime propaganda vehicles posing as mystery movies always sort of leave me cold, in this case despite decent performances from a talented cast.

credits[4].name: Walter Kingsford
credits[5].name: Miles Mander

credits[3].name: Cedric Hardwicke
credits[4].name: Ralph Bellamy
credits[5].name: Lionel Atwill

credits[5].name: Willie Best

credits[4].name: Cedric Hardwicke
credits[5].name: J. Edward Bromberg

credits[4].name: Glenn Strange
credits[5].name: Sarah Padden

title: The Man Who Wouldn't Die

credits[2].name: Marjorie Weaver
credits[3].name: Helene Reynolds
credits[4].name: Henry Wilcoxon
credits[5].name: Richard Derr

title: The Mummy's Tomb

credits[3].name: Dick Foran
credits[4].name: Elyse Knox
credits[5].name: John Hubbard

credits[3].name: Maria Ouspenskaya
credits[4].name: John Litel
credits[5].name: Edward Norris

title: Night Monster

credits[4].name: Irene Hervey

credits[4].name: Marjorie Hoshelle
credits[5].name: Robert Kent
description: Warner Brothers didn't invest much in the way of scriptwriting or acting talent in this nonsensical murder mystery involving the usual wisecracking detective galavanting through crime scenes like a loose cannon and then finally solving the case via preposterous reasoning.

title: Frankenstein Meets the Wolfman
credits[0].name: Roy William Neill
credits[1].name: Bela Lugosi
credits[2].name: Lon Chaney Jr.
credits[3].name: Ilona Massey
credits[4].name: Patric Knowles
credits[5].name: Lionel Atwill
description: Nobody can wallow in melodramatic self-pity like Chaney's Talbot, which is not as off-putting as it sounds when you consider his dilemma; also Lugosi playing the Frankenstein monster delivers an interesting twist.

title: The Ghost Ship
credits[0].name: Mark Robson
credits[1].name: Richard Dix
credits[2].name: Russel Wade
credits[3].name: Edith Barrett
credits[4].name: Ben Bard
credits[5].name: Edmund Glover
description: Producer Val Lewton's trademark black-and-white moodiness is on full display in this psychological thriller about a mad sea captain with murderous intent.

title: I Walked with a Zombie
credits[0].name: Jacques Tourneur
credits[1].name: James Ellison
credits[2].name: Frances Dee
credits[3].name: Tom Conway
credits[4].name: Edith Barrett
credits[5].name: James Bell
description: Val Lewton and Jacques Tourneur team up again to deliver this visually stunning story based loosely on Jane Eyre, highlighted by the quintessentially creepy cane field scene.

title: The Leopard Man
credits[0].name: Jacques Tourneur
credits[1].name: Dennis O'Keefe
credits[2].name: Margo
credits[3].name: Jean Brooks
credits[4].name: Isabel Jewell
credits[5].name: James Bell
description: Adapting a Cornell Woolrich novel, Lewton and Tourneur render another masterpiece of quiet foreboding: the scene where the gypsy girl is locked out of her house by her mother will make your blood curdle.

title: The Mad Ghoul
credits[0].name: James P. Hogan
credits[1].name: David Bruce
credits[2].name: Evelyn Ankers
credits[3].name: George Zucco
credits[4].name: Robert Armstrong
credits[5].name: Turhan Bey
description: Universal's exemplary production values cannot save this disappointment, which despite a top-tier cast founders due to its weakly-written story.

title: The Mysterious Doctor
credits[0].name: Benjamin Stoloff
credits[1].name: John Loder
credits[2].name: Eleanor Parker
credits[3].name: Bruce Lester
credits[4].name: Lester Matthews
credits[5].name: Forrester Harvey
description: Starts off very promisingly with a chilling graveyard scene featuring the headless knight of local legend in a Cornish country village, but soon devolves into more standard wartime propagandistic fare.

title: Phantom of the Opera
credits[0].name: Arthur Lubin
credits[1].name: Nelson Eddy
credits[2].name: Susanna Foster
credits[3].name: Claude Rains
credits[4].name: Edgar Barrier
credits[5].name: Leo Carrillo
description: Pretty decent Technicolor remake from Universal of their own silent-era classic; certainly lacking the creep factor of the original, but with Nelson Eddy performing admirably in the opera scenes.

title: The Seventh Victim
credits[0].name: Mark Robson
credits[1].name: Tom Conway
credits[2].name: Jean Brooks
credits[3].name: Isabel Jewell
credits[4].name: Kim Hunter
credits[5].name: Hugh Beaumont
description: The Beaver's dad stars in this eeriest of Val Lewton's productions (which IS really saying something) about devil worship and vanished siblings.

title: Sherlock Holmes and the Secret Weapon
credits[0].name: Roy William Neill
credits[1].name: Basil Rathbone
credits[2].name: Nigel Bruce
credits[3].name: Lionel Atwill
credits[4].name: Kaaren Verne
credits[5].name: William Post Jr.
description: It's bad enough that Holmes and Watson ply their trade in 20th-century London, but in this otherwise unnoteworthy installment Rathbone also sports a truly horrendous beatnik-looking hairdo.

title: Sherlock Holmes Faces Death
credits[0].name: Roy William Neill
credits[1].name: Basil Rathbone
credits[2].name: Nigel Bruce
credits[3].name: Dennis Hoey
credits[4].name: Arthur Margetson
credits[5].name: Hillary Brooke
description: In the sixth Rathbone/Bruce installment from Universal, director Neill evokes loads of creepy Northumberland-like atmosphere, and does a nice job of incorporating elements from Conan Doyle's Musgrave Ritual" into the story."

title: Sherlock Holmes in Washington
credits[0].name: Roy William Neill
credits[1].name: Basil Rathbone
credits[2].name: Nigel Bruce
credits[3].name: Marjorie Lord
credits[4].name: Henry Daniell
credits[5].name: George Zucco
description: In spite of the all-too-common misplacement of the master sleuth smack in the middle of the wrong century, this turns out to be a well-told and hair-raising unraveling of a neat little mystery involving an international spy ring.

title: Son of Dracula
credits[0].name: Robert Siodmak
credits[1].name: Lon Chaney Jr.
credits[2].name: Robert Paige
credits[3].name: Louise Allbritton
credits[4].name: Evelyn Akers
credits[5].name: Frank Craven
description: Surprising that five or six centuries of accumulated wisdom didn't enable Drac's boy to come up with a better alias than Count Alucard, although Chaney Jr. does make a nicely menacing vampire despite the mustache.

title: The Uninvited
credits[0].name: Lewis Allen
credits[1].name: Ray Milland
credits[2].name: Ruth Hussey
credits[3].name: Donald Crisp
credits[4].name: Cornelia Otis Skinner
credits[5].name: Dorothy Stickney
description: The setting, an old manor house on the coast of Cornwall, is particularly suited to this well-constructed, spine-chilling tale of haunting spirits and mysterious motives.

title: Arsenic and Old Lace
credits[0].name: Frank Capra
credits[1].name: Cary Grant
credits[2].name: Josephine Hull
credits[3].name: Jean Adair
credits[4].name: Raymond Massey
credits[5].name: Peter Lorre
description: Nobody'd be able pull off such an over-the-top portrayal of Mortimer Brewster except Cary Grant.

title: Bluebeard
credits[0].name: Edgar G. Ulmar
credits[1].name: John Carradine
credits[2].name: Jean Parker
credits[3].name: Nils Asther
credits[4].name: Ludwig Stossel
credits[5].name: George Pembroke
description: John Carradine himself credited this as his best work, and as usual Ulmar delivers well-rendered atmospherics in this 19th century PRC period piece set in Paris.

title: Candles at Nine
credits[0].name: John Harlow
credits[1].name: Eliot Makeham
credits[2].name: Beatrix Lehmann
credits[3].name: John Salew
credits[4].name: Joss Ambler
credits[5].name: Vera Bogetti
description: I struggled valiantly during three separate viewings to stay awake through this movie, a British old dark house murder mystery, but I was foiled on each occasion owing to the dearth of charisma in the leads and the utterly uncompelling storyline.

title: The Canterville Ghost
credits[0].name: Jules Dassin
credits[1].name: Charles Laughton
credits[2].name: Robert Young
credits[3].name: Margaret O'Brien
credits[4].name: William Gargen
credits[5].name: Reginald Owen
description: MGM's lofty production values do not begin to make up for an unbearably hokey script, an uncharacteristically humdrum performance by Charles Laughton, and of course the ever-cloying Miss O'Brien.

title: Curse of the Cat People
credits[0].name: Gunther von Fritsch
credits[1].name: Robert Wise
credits[2].name: Jane Randolph
credits[3].name: Ann Carter
credits[4].name: Simone Simon
credits[5].name: Kent Smith
description: Val Lewton's magnum opus, demonstrating his absolute mastery of mood and lighting effects, in the service of a haunting tale of childhood imagination.

title: Gaslight
credits[0].name: George Cukor
credits[1].name: Charles Boyer
credits[2].name: Ingrid Bergman
credits[3].name: Joseph Cotten
credits[4].name: Dame May Whitty
credits[5].name: Angela Lansbury
description: In a psychological thriller such as this, the all-important ingredient is a sympathetic portrayal of the victim, and Bergman earned well her Oscar for her nuanced and evocative performance.

title: House of Frankenstein
credits[0].name: Erle C. Kenton
credits[1].name: Boris Karloff
credits[2].name: Lon Chaney Jr.
credits[3].name: John Carradine
credits[4].name: Anne Gwynne
credits[5].name: Lionel Atwill
description: A nicely-turned plot and a stable of Universal regulars (minus the conspicuously-absent Lugosi) lend this film its aura, which is only enhanced by the confluence of the studio's three top monsters.

title: The Invisible Man's Revenge
credits[0].name: Ford Beebe
credits[1].name: Jon Hall
credits[2].name: Leon Errol
credits[3].name: John Carradine
credits[4].name: Evelyn Ankers
credits[5].name: Alan Curtis
description: The tried-and-true invisibility effects abound here, and the story has a fairly interesting twist, but ultimately it's more of the same stuff we've seen in previous Invisible Man sequels.

title: Jungle Woman
credits[0].name: Reginald Le Borg
credits[1].name: Acquanetta
credits[2].name: Evelyn Ankers
credits[3].name: J. Carrol Naish
credits[4].name: Samuel S. Hinds
credits[5].name: Lois Collier
description: Acquanetta's back as Paula Dupree, Universal's ape woman, and aside from the nearly twenty minutes of footage recycled from the earlier Captive Wild Woman, this is a fairly engaging tale of unrequited beastly love.

title: Laura
credits[0].name: Otto Preminger
credits[1].name: Gene Tierney
credits[2].name: Dana Andrews
credits[3].name: Clifton Webb
credits[4].name: Vincent Price
credits[5].name: Judith Anderson
description: Gene Tierney is mesmerizing as the title character, but the stilted dialog and stiff character portrayals detract from what is otherwise a nicely turned film noir murder mystery.

title: The Lodger
credits[0].name: John Brahm
credits[1].name: Merle Oberon
credits[2].name: George Sanders
credits[3].name: Laird Cregar
credits[4].name: Cedric Hardwicke
credits[5].name: Sara Allgood
description: The most overrated of overrated director John Brahm's creations, featuring a great deal of scenery crunching by Laird Cregar, and music hall antics with ludicrous costumery completely out of place for 19th century England.

title: Ministry of Fear
credits[0].name: Fritz Lang
credits[1].name: Ray Milland
credits[2].name: Marjorie Reynolds
credits[3].name: Carl Esmond
credits[4].name: Hillary Brooke
credits[5].name: Percy Waram
description: More conventional than you'd expect from Fritz Lang, but still an absorbingly suspenseful noir mystery with a couple of nice twists and an effective performance by Ray Milland.

title: The Monster Maker
credits[0].name: Sam Newfield
credits[1].name: J. Carrol Naish
credits[2].name: Ralph Morgan
credits[3].name: Tala Birell
credits[4].name: Wanda McKay
credits[5].name: Terry Frost
description: The twisted, sadistic means used by the fiendish doctor to achieve his lecherous intentions is what provides the entertainment value in this poverty row shocker from PRC.

title: The Mummy's Curse
credits[0].name: Leslie Goodwins
credits[1].name: Lon Chaney Jr.
credits[2].name: Peter Coe
credits[3].name: Virginia Christine
credits[4].name: Kay Harding
credits[5].name: Dennis Moore
description: Why bother considering trivial questions such as what's the mummy doing in the Louisiana bayou, when you can watch Lon Chaney Jr. chasing around the Princess Ananka in this Universal laugher?

title: The Mummy's Ghost
credits[0].name: Reginald Le Borg
credits[1].name: John Carradine
credits[2].name: Lon Chaney Jr.
credits[3].name: Robert Lowery
credits[4].name: Ramsay Ames
credits[5].name: George Zucco
description: It's hard to tell these Mummy sequels apart, but this entry is distinguished by John Carradine as the feeder of tana leaves to Chaney Jr.'s Kharis, and by George Zucco's brief return as the High Priest.

title: One Body Too Many
credits[0].name: Frank McDonald
credits[1].name: Bela Lugosi
credits[2].name: Jean Parker
credits[3].name: Jack Haley
credits[4].name: Lyle Talbot
credits[5].name: Blanche Yurka
description: A lighthearted dark-house/inheritance mystery with some pleasantly creepy sequences and some offbeat performances, especially by Lugosi as the dubious butler.

title: One Mysterious Night
credits[0].name: Bud Boetticher
credits[1].name: Chester Morris
credits[2].name: Janis Carter
credits[3].name: William Wright
credits[4].name: Richard Lane
credits[5].name: George E. Stone
description: Chester Morris makes a charismatic Boston Blackie careening through one hair-raising plot turn after another, but this potboiler from Columbia suffers from just a few too many preposterous situations.

title: The Pearl of Death
credits[0].name: Roy William Neill
credits[1].name: Basil Rathbone
credits[2].name: Nigel Bruce
credits[3].name: Dennis Hoey
credits[4].name: Evelyn Ankers
credits[5].name: Miles Mander
description: After a truly engaging setup, this ninth Universal Sherlock Holmes mystery starring Basil Rathbone and Nigel Bruce loses a lot of steam in succumbing to a rather gimmicky ending.

title: Return of the Vampire
credits[0].name: Lew Landers
credits[1].name: Bela Lugosi
credits[2].name: Frieda Inescort
credits[3].name: Nina Foch
credits[4].name: Miles Mander
credits[5].name: Matt Willis
description: In this wartime monster flick Frieda Inescort plays Lady Jane Ainsley, a role that, in a refreshing departure from form, has a woman vanquishing evil in ways that were usually the domain of a leading man.

title: The Scarlet Claw
credits[0].name: Roy William Neill
credits[1].name: Basil Rathbone
credits[2].name: Nigel Bruce
credits[3].name: Gerald Hamer
credits[4].name: Paul Cavanagh
credits[5].name: Kay Harding
description: Although unfortunately this Sherlock Holmes mystery from Universal takes place in the twentieth century, its atmosphere and spirit are purely Victorian,  and there are refreshing touches of expressionism in the settings and camera work.

title: The Spider Woman
credits[0].name: Roy William Neill
credits[1].name: Basil Rathbone
credits[2].name: Nigel Bruce
credits[3].name: Gale Sondergaard
credits[4].name: Dennis Hoey
credits[5].name: Vernon Downing
description: Sherlock Holmes is almost foiled by a woman in this harebrained mystery featuring hardly any suspense and a completely implausible murder-for-profit scheme.

title: Voodoo Man
credits[0].name: William Beaudine
credits[1].name: Bela Lugosi
credits[2].name: John Carradine
credits[3].name: George Zucco
credits[4].name: Wanda McKay
credits[5].name: Louise Currie
description: Can't really determine whether Lugosi's young female victims are put into their trances by way of voodoo or hypnosis; but never mind, it's a thoroughly enjoyable ride highlighted by Carradine's outrageous Toby.

title: And Then There Were None
credits[0].name: Rene Clair
credits[1].name: Barry Fitzgerald
credits[2].name: Walter Huston
credits[3].name: Louis Hayward
credits[4].name: Roland Young
credits[5].name: June Duprez
description: A highly accomplished cast favors this rendition of the Agatha Christie novel, which unfortunately is compromised by the fact that in film it's very difficult to mask the utter implausibility of the events as they unfold.

title: Bewitched
credits[0].name: Arch Oboler
credits[1].name: Phyllis Thaxter
credits[2].name: Edmund Gwenn
credits[3].name: Henry H. Daniels Jr.
credits[4].name: Addison Richards
credits[5].name: Kathleen Lockhart
description: This MGM thriller starts off promisingly, with fiendish voices besetting the young heroine and driving her from her hometown, but it devolves into parboiled psychobabble for the denouement.

title: Blithe Spirit
credits[0].name: David Lean
credits[1].name: Rex Harrison
credits[2].name: Constance Cummings
credits[3].name: Kay Hammond
credits[4].name: Margaret Rutherford
credits[5].name: Hugh Wakefield
description: With dialog very faithful to the Noel Coward play on which it''s based, this ghostly comedy has plenty of wit, but the two leading ladies simply can''t muster the charisma to stand up to aces like Harrison and Rutherford.

title: The Body Snatcher
credits[0].name: Robert Wise
credits[1].name: Boris Karloff
credits[2].name: Bela Lugosi
credits[3].name: Henry Daniell
credits[4].name: Edith Atwater
credits[5].name: Russell Wade
description: Karloff shines in the role of the tormented doctor who goes too far in obtaining cadavers for his research in this typically chilling Lewton gem epitomized by the scene wherein the gypsy girl's haunting melody is abruptly cut short.

title: Dead of Night
credits[0].name: Alberto Cavalcanti
credits[1].name: Charles Crichton
credits[2].name: Basil Deardon
credits[3].name: Robert Hamer
credits[4].name: Michael Redgrave
credits[5].name: Googie Whithers
description: Five mostly high-caliber ghost stories are linked together through the telling over tea and drinks at an English country house, culminating in a somewhat disjointed climax of the connecting story.

title: Fog Island
credits[0].name: Terry O. Morse
credits[1].name: George Zucco
credits[2].name: Lionell Atwill
credits[3].name: Jerome Cowan
credits[4].name: Sharon Douglas
credits[5].name: Veda Ann Borg
description: This outing gets credit for the atmospheric charm of its settings, and for the fact that so many of the main characters end up meeting their deaths in unspeakable  manners, but the storyline is feeble and confused.

title: Hangover Square
credits[0].name: John Brahm
credits[1].name: Laird Cregar
credits[2].name: Linda Darnell
credits[3].name: George Sanders
credits[4].name: Faye Marlowe
credits[5].name: Faye Marlowe
description: Despite top-notch production values and a compelling performance by Laird Cregar as the lead, this film is fairly flat until Linda Darnell swoops in and livens things up a bit.

title: House of Dracula
credits[0].name: Erle C. Kenton
credits[1].name: Lon Chaney Jr.
credits[2].name: John Carradine
credits[3].name: Martha O'Driscoll
credits[4].name: Lionel Atwill
credits[5].name: Onslow Stevens
description: The sets are gorgeous, the cast is first-rate, the script is... well, pretty lame; plus we have to endure a very cheesily mustachioed Dracula.

title: The House of Fear
credits[0].name: Roy William Neill
credits[1].name: Basil Rathbone
credits[2].name: Nigel Bruce
credits[3].name: Aubrey Mather
credits[4].name: Dennis Hoey
credits[5].name: Paul Cavanagh
description: Making excellent use of Universal's magnificently atmospheric sets, this Sherlock Holmes detective mystery stays uncharacteristically true to the original Conan Doyle story The Five Orange Pips.""

title: The House on 92nd Street
credits[0].name: Henry Hathaway
credits[1].name: William Eythe
credits[2].name: Lloyd Nolan
credits[3].name: Signe Hasso
credits[4].name: Gene Lockhart
credits[5].name: Leo G. Carroll
description: An effective wartime spy thriller, this Fox Studios production features an especially menacing performance by Ms. Hasso as the sinister head of a Nazi cell stationed in New York City.

title: I Love a Mystery
credits[0].name: Henry Levin
credits[1].name: Jim Bannon
credits[2].name: Nina Foch
credits[3].name: George Macready
credits[4].name: Boston Yarborough
credits[5].name: Carole Mathews
description: From the opening decapitation, this potboiler from Columbia spins a jerky and unpredictable tale of mystery and foreboding, complete with a secret Tibetan society and a deliciously scheming Nina Foch as the victim's wife.

title: Isle of the Dead
credits[0].name: Mark Robson
credits[1].name: Boris Karloff
credits[2].name: Ellen Drew
credits[3].name: Marc Cramer
credits[4].name: Katherine Emery
credits[5].name: Helene Thimig
description: Even by Val Lewton standards this movie is weird, with Karloff in charge of a quarantined Greek island, and featuring a ghost-like apparition roaming the tombs where she'd been interred only hours earlier.

title: Jungle Captive
credits[0].name: Harold Young
credits[1].name: Otto Kruger
credits[2].name: Vicky Lane
credits[3].name: Amelita Ward
credits[4].name: Phil Brown
credits[5].name: Jerome Cowan
description: This is a sub-par, threadbare follow-on to Universal's Captive Wild Woman" and "Jungle Woman"
column20: with the unfortunate Ms. Lane taking over for Acquanetta in the role of the ape woman."

title: The Phantom of 42nd Street
credits[0].name: Albert Herman
credits[1].name: Dave O'Brien
credits[2].name: Kay Aldridge
credits[3].name: Alan Mowbray
credits[4].name: Frank Jenks
credits[5].name: Edythe Elliott
description: A nicely-plotted murder mystery from PRC which suffers from some stiff acting by Dave O'Brien as the theater critic turned detective.

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
credits[0].name: Albert Lewin
credits[1].name: George Sanders
credits[2].name: Hurd Hatfield
credits[3].name: Donna Reed
credits[4].name: Angela Lansbury
credits[5].name: Peter Lawford
description: Despite the star-studded cast, it's the somber, evocative, Oscar-winning cinematography that sets this movie apart.

title: Pursuit to Algiers
credits[0].name: Roy William Neill
credits[1].name: Basil Rathbone
credits[2].name: Nigel Bruce
credits[3].name: Marjorie Riordan
credits[4].name: Rosalind Ivan
credits[5].name: Morton Lowry
description: Of course Basil Rathbone is inimitable as Sherlock Holmes, but by the time of this twelfth entry Universal's series seems to have lost its knack for creating any genuine air of mystery.

title: The Vampire's Ghost
credits[0].name: Lesley Selander
credits[1].name: John Abbott
credits[2].name: Charles Gordon
credits[3].name: Peggy Stewart
credits[4].name: Grant Withers
credits[5].name: Emmett Vogan
description: This well-plotted and atmospheric vampire story from Republic distinguishes itself with its African setting and offbeat villain, but it's the hot gypsy dance performed by Adele Mara that virtually steals the picture.

title: The Woman in Green
credits[0].name: Roy William Neill
credits[1].name: Basil Rathbone
credits[2].name: Nigel Bruce
credits[3].name: Hillary Brooke
credits[4].name: Henry Daniell
credits[5].name: Paul Cavanagh
description: Featuring Rathbone in his eleventh turn as Sherlock Holmes for Universal, this story at first elicits genuine horror at the ghoulish murders he's to solve, but in the end this gives way to unconvincing superhero-type antics.

title: The Woman Who Came Back
credits[0].name: Walter Colmes
credits[1].name: John Loder
credits[2].name: Nancy Kelly
credits[3].name: Otto Kruger
credits[4].name: Ruth Ford
credits[5].name: Harry Tyler
description: This film sets exactly the right tone for the story of a smalltown witch's vengeful curse, but as is all-too-common with horror pieces of the mid- to late forties it devolves into a psychodrama where most of the conflict takes place inside Ms. Kelly's head.
